Pre-Game Insights: Harry Kane and Jude Bellingham enjoying themselves at Euro 2024 (Carl Recine/Getty Images)
Gareth Southgate meeting fans in Germany this week (Richard Pelham/Getty Images)
Miscellaneous Highlights: The FA has done lots of work to ensure that each player’s bedroom in their Blankenhain base in Germany for this tournament feels homely — which includes hanging AI-generated pictures of their dogs on their wall.

Star of the show is Conor Gallagher’s chow chow, but there are also dogs belonging to Jordan Pickford (cavapoo), Eberechi Eze (shar pei), Harry Kane (chocolate labrador), Lewis Dunk (two cockapoos), Aaron Ramsdale (another chow chow), Dean Henderson (rottweiler) and Anthony Gordon (it’s some sort of fluffy thing, I don’t know the breed but I know for a fact it is named Barney).
A further seven players also own dogs — creating a total of 15 England players (or 58 per cent).
Phil Foden’s is named Carabao after the cup.
Declan Rice, Gordon and Gallagher took part in a Crufts-style dog training challenge last month as part of Channel 4’s coverage.
Others: The England team face Switzerland today (Saturday) in the quarter-finals, but before heading along to the game The Athletic’s England writers attempted to explain, among other things, why Harry Kane keeps trying to be a midfielder, what it will be like if they lose, who can do the most keepy-uppies, who has the biggest feet and how many of the players have dogs.
England haven’t won a major tournament since 1966 and so it’s not a failure by these players if they don’t win this one.
The Olympic football tournaments, one for men and one for women, start just 10 days after the Euro 2024 ends on July 14.
